text:
I understand L4D2 is an absolutely beloved game by a lot of people, but personally I don't really see the appeal. I'm sure a lot of people will find this opinion appalling but I'm being 100% honest when I say I didn't have much fun with the game.

I tried playing this friends, and 2 out of the 3 of us ended up feeling that there wasn't anything unique enough about the game to warrant continuing. My main problem is that despite being a flagship co-op game, there really isn't a lot that brings you together. Some zombies people need saving from, others need more firepower to take down, but the game is pretty bare bones and it never felt like we were working together all that much. I'm sure higher difficulties require you to get more coordinated, but there isn't really a good balance between it being incredibly difficult and dreadfully easy in my experience.

Overall I'd rate my experience like a 4/10. I can get why others enjoy it, but to my eyes, this is about as by the numbers as you can get for a co-op shooter.

text:
Coop campaigns are fucking perfect. Seriously little to no complaint there. Versus, which had huge potential as a source cooperative team based pvp with a surprising amount of depth and coordination, is honestly shit at this point. There's no tutorial or explanation or advice given to players who queue up. If you don't know anyone who plays versus, or can't find someone with patience who is willing to help you learn, its most likely not worth your time. It's common practice to check hours of players in this game. An abundance of cheaters. If you wait long enough to get a lobby together, if its stacked its more or less hopeless unless you start trying to kick your teammates in hopes of a better replacement. If you're bad at the game, good chance someone will try to votekick you, and ironically its kinda hard to know what you're doing in versus without failing many many times. You might make it damn near to the end of a campaign only to have the lobby fall apart from one sore loser leaving and kicking off a cascade. Valve does not offer any sort of proper support for this mode, evident by a large amount of server abuse causing redirects to russian connections or just straight up having the game servers ddosed. If you can get past the thorns, and dont take it too seriously, and are willing to keep trying over and over until you get a tolerable lobby, versus is a gem. Valve could really have done so much to support this mode better and divert it from the caustic baby spittle it is now, but l4d2 aint unique in that regard. Play the campaign, do the survival achievements, have fun with the workshop. If u decide to do versus then good luck lol. game still fun tho ;p

text:
Left 4 Dead 2, where do I even begin? This game has been a constant source of anguish and frustration, pushing me to the brink of insanity with its unforgiving zombie hordes and brain-dead teammates. It's like trying to survive the apocalypse with a pack of malfunctioning toasters for companions.

Let's talk about the people I've encountered in this game. Half the time, they're about as useful as a chocolate teapot, stumbling around like drunken squirrels and shooting at everything except the actual zombies. It's like they have a death wish or a secret desire to see us all become zombie chow.

And don't even get me started on the zombie difficulty. It's like the game takes sadistic pleasure in throwing wave after wave of undead monstrosities at you, each one more relentless and infuriating than the last. It's enough to make you want to scream into the void and never look back.

But despite all the rage-inducing moments, I have to admit, the characters are funny. Their banter and one-liners provide a brief respite from the unrelenting chaos, like a flickering candle in the midst of a raging storm. And the design of the levels and weapons is undeniably fun, offering a sense of satisfaction when you mow down a horde of zombies with a chainsaw or blast them to smithereens with a grenade launcher.

But let's be real hereâ€”Left 4 Dead 2 is a testament to frustration and futility. It's like trying to swim upstream in a river of molasses, with every step forward met with two steps back. And while some may find enjoyment in the chaos, for me, it's nothing but a never-ending nightmareâ€”a reminder that sometimes, even the best-laid plans can go horribly, horribly wrong.

Do i love this game? Yes

Can i recommend it? Only if playing offline or with friends.

L4D2's community is toxic but so are all source engine communities. Every other game will have someone spam N*****, spam some form of hate speech, or that one guy who downtalks everyone when he can barely keep himself alive.

Hate speech is one thing, but also this games community also hates new players, ive played since the survival pack dropped the 2nd week of L4D1's release on console so ive gotten better over time, but new players are expected to rush maps, know all likely si spawns, know where to sync with other teammates, know how to play every si, and know which items to use and when. All of these things seem like things youd learn with experience right? well if you mess up once about 2/3 of the time youll be kicked, and once you do get better you HAVE to also follow this kick rule if you ever want a chance at winning.

Ok, ok... the community is bad we get it, but if i knew all these things and ignored the hate speech, what then?

well now you have to deal with cheaters, ddos'ing, scripters, and griefers.

DDOS'ing in this game is more often in this game than any other, you WILL get DDOS'd and might even have some jimmy loser put you on a bot list to auto ddos you.

aimbotting and cheating is common. scripts like auto bhop is even more often (like 2/3 servers you play, just open console and look for "file denied 000000.dat" and someone is using a script)

also expect people to suicide, friendly fire, and team swap then grief.

So youll have to deal with all of the above, and the people you play against in vs are mostly losers like me with thousands of hours on the game. So even tho this is one of my favorite games, i cannot recommend anyone get it.

This review is a peculiar one because I do see why this game is supposed to be so great, when it works it is great for some even perfect. I can not sit here denying that I did not have a fun time, the game is fun and my writing a "negative" review is mostly my fault. I expected a completely different game and that's on me.
But if you asked me would recommend this game I would not be able to give you a cohesive answer,

On the one hand, this game is a masterpiece if you just wanna kill zombies in a whacky world.
On the other one, the game seems to show its age.
On several occasions, a large horde of zombies simply got stuck in a doorway with them infinitely respawning leading to a soft lock.
The other problem I have is the pacing. They throw all these enemies at you from the get-go so there is no tension or anything. From level 3 onwards I did not even feel the slightest amount of joy when I saw a new enemy cause I knew they were just going to be there and then dead, no build no nothing.

Short verdict:
-Great game
-Not for me
-Something you should check out if it interests you
-personally would not buy this for full price.

text:
This is a great Zombie co-op shooter, there is no doubt about that. Apart from the fact that you get snared when hit and your movement speed drops as your health decreases, not much can be said about the core game's flaws. I mean, it would be nice for them to add Aim Down Sights (ADS) like every other modern FPS, but that's probably a limitation on the engine, so whatever.

One thing that I don't understand, is why it is so difficult to get into a game of Versus. 17 thousand players currently online, and yet there is only one game currently one, with zero lobbies. How does that make sense? Are they all bots? Is L4D2 just filled with bots, how is it possible that I can only get one game with 17k players on?

But the community for this game is so unbelievably toxic, probably one of the most toxic in gaming. This is made even worse when you can't mute individual people and the fact that the host does not hold any veto power on members. Meaning, you can have one toxic and rude player join the game, have his friends join and kick out the original host. That, and the fact the community is so unwelcoming towards new players. You're new and you don't know how to bunny hop? Kicked. You don't save someone as they die from their own mistake? Kicked. In my 30 hours of playing this game, I can't say that I hold any positive experiences from playing online with randoms, just pure negativity and toxicity.

This is made all the worse when there is no report system in game, meaning that there is no way for Valve to deal with those players. I find it ironic that Valve is all about creating a welcoming community and ensuring that hate speech and toxicity has no place on Steam, and yet L4D2 is one of the most toxic games I have ever played, even more so than League of Legends.

text:
Here's the ProCons on L4D2

Pros
- Simple to jump into, it's not very complex with the gameplay, shoot zombies, get to places, only a few buttons to press, basically console level simplicity.
- Has campaigns you can play through which is the best part of L4D2 with a variety of locations you can go through.
- mods, if that's your thing.
- No Skills, By that I mean the survivors don't have anything that would make one better than the other outside of cosmetics and voice lines. You can pick any character and they function the same.
- Versus, it can be fun.
- fun with people/friends/buddies.

Cons
- Lack of 'substance', The game is quite basic with the weapons and things you can do. Basically variety is very minimal. They added more items since L4D1 but it's not much.
- no individuality, all survivors control and work the same. They don't have anything unique to them that affects gameplay except for cosmetics. While it makes it balanced for everyone, I find that boring. could have skills that give your player something unique.
- Gunplay feels like empty, there's no 'punch/kick' to the weapons. it doesn't feel like I just blasted a zombie with satisfaction it feels like the zombies just take the bullets, checks how much life it has left, dies if it's less than zero.
- weapon variety is basic, it's just pistol, shotgun, rifle, and sniper rifle. very basic and boring.
- 'forced' teamwork gameplay, you're forced to play as team as oppose to being suggested to play as a team. 
If you don't play as a team you get punished by infected that incapacitate you if you end up alone. I don't enjoy how pathetic your characters are at be incapable of saving themselves. It should have had more options for you to survive by yourself when you're caught in those situations BUT at a greater cost than if you worked as a team. Now that is making teamworking an option and not forced upon you.
- multiplayer lag/desync. I unload a whole magazine into a special infect and it doesn't die because lag/desync had them elsewhere according to the game.
- bots suck, play with people.

Overall L4D2 is a decent game that could be better. I wouldn't play it alone, but if people invited sure.

text:
This finally feels like an opportune time to give a proper verdict.

Being plagued with the curse of having ethical standards enables me to give the following statements.

Enjoying the luxury of post-launch syndrome on behalf of the developers is a good reason to assume why the so called [b][u]SEQUEL[/u][/b] to [url=https://store.steampowered.com/app/500/Left_4_Dead/]Left for Dead[/url] was not released in a complete, polished state:

Thank god for the TLS team who took time out of their lives to fix issues regarding...
[list]
[*]vocalisations - missing, unported lines and broken initiation sequences (some of them being campaign specific);
[*]incomplete/incorrect, or flatout MISSING animation sequences (gestures/callouts) in thirdperson Survivor mode when utilising vocalisation;
- This behaviour could be observed in Pre-TLS releases, where in local server environments one would see gestures of their Survivor character if in [b]thirdpersonshoulder[/b] mode, whereas in dedicated server environments such behaviour is non-existent, spamming the client console with red outlined messages for MISSING animation sequences.

[*]missing melee models on the back of L4D1 Survivor models, once again observed when in thirdperson mode, or when looking at team members;
[*]C6M3 (The Passing) ending sequence released in a broken state (Zoey model).
[*]The lack of animation bobbing on the 9mm pistol for single and dual wielding.
[*]Some characters had the wrong skeleton animations (Rochelle?).
[/list]

L4D1 Survivors not carrying over their (Tier 2) weapon preference from the original game into this one. Because they are just lazily pasted over the L4D2 cast and calling it a day. Nice!
Apparently this has been [url=https://i.postimg.cc/N0r9Rp01/l4d1-survivor-weapon-preference.png]fixed[/url] in TLS, but I have not observed it myself.

First person legs missing, which were [b][u]prevalent[/u][/b] and [b][u]intact[/u][/b] in Left for Dead 1? Console ports have disadvantages, clearly.

[b]NOTE:[/b] I am quite aware of the existence of the [url=https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2865107042]Legs add-on[/url] in the Workshop. In fact I have used L4D2 legs way before it was there, as a SourcePawn plug-in server-side. From what I could remember it is a VScript fork of Ludastar's work in the [url=https://forums.alliedmods.net/showthread.php?p=2536139]Allied Modders forum[/url]. This still does not excuse releasing an inferior product, compared to the original, and calling it a sequel to said original.

[h1]THAT BEING SAID HOWEVER[/h1]
Here is a list of a few [b][u]positive[/u][/b] aspects Left for Dead 2 has now, which it did not have before. This may not benefit me, but it probably benefits more recent lease-payers.
[list]
[*]Left for Dead 2's license used to be 14,99 euros, later it changed to 8,19 euros. Now it is 9,75 euros. Every major sale (so far) and since the last price adjustment, both Left for Dead game licenses are on sale for 90% off (0,97 euros).
[*]The game is in a state, which I consider the most playable it has ever been. Earlier releases had had more problems overall. This is chiefly thanks to TLS and other non-Valve affiliated sources.
[*]Workshop is so oversaturated with content there is something for almost everyone.
[/list]

[u]MISCELLANEOUS STUFF[/u]
[list]
[*]There is a [url=https://steamcommunity.com/groups/L4D2boycott]group[/url] which used to stand against Left for Dead 2's early release (only one year after Left for Dead released). This group mainly protested in fear of Left for Dead 1's abandonment and shelf life, however. I am posting this information in order to inform those whom are unaware of Left for Dead 2's release date not being well received by all. And for a good reason.
[*]Last time I checked there are still Official Linux servers provided by Valve.*
[/list]

[i]*This is subject to change at any time, as neither Valve nor anyone else are obligated to keep providing servers for players. Code-wise this game is built on the client-server relationship. There are tools available for free which enable you to create such environments. One is [url=https://developer.valvesoftware.com/wiki/SteamCMD]SteamCMD[/url].[/i]

What stands out the most is the fact it took almost [b][u]ELEVEN[/u][/b] years for Valve's "sequel" to be polished on PC.

Left for Dead 2 first released in November 2009.

TLS rolled out in September 2020. [url=https://store.steampowered.com/oldnews/75849]News article[/url]

Of course, one would wonder whether such a thing would have happened if Valve did not depend on its convenience store (known as Steam), giving them the privilege of not fixing their product before launch.

Take it as you must.

For the crust: Adjust an oven rack to the middle position and heat the oven to 325Â°. Process the graham cracker pieces in a food processor to fine, even crumbs, about 30 seconds. Sprinkle the melted butter and sugar over the crumbs and pulse to incorporate. Sprinkle the mixture into a 9-inch springform pan. Press the crumbs firmly into an even layer using the bottom of a measuring cup. Bake the crust until fragrant and beginning to brown, 10 to 15 minutes. Let the crust cool to room temperature, about 30 minutes.

For the filling: Meanwhile, increase the oven temperature to 500Â°. Beat the cream cheese in a large bowl with an electric mixer on medium-low speed until smooth, 1-3 minutes. Scrape down the bowl and beaters as necessary.

Beat in half the sugar and salt until incorporated, 1-3 minutes. Beat in the remaining sugar until incorporated, 1-3 minutes. Beat in the sour cream, lemon juice and vanilla until incorporated, 1-3 minutes. Beat in the egg yolks and eggs, two at a time until combined, 1-3 minutes.

Being careful not to disturb the baked crust, brush the inside of the prepared springform pan with 1 tablespoon of melted butter. Set the pan on a rimmed baking sheet. Carefully pour the filling into the pan. Bake the cheesecake for 10 minutes.

Without opening the door, reduce the oven temperature to 200Â° and continue to bake the cheesecake until the center of the cake registers 150Â° (about 1 1/2 hours).

Transfer the cake to a wire rack and run a knife around the edge of the cake. Let the cheesecake stand until just barely warm, 2 1/2 â€“ 3 hours. Chill until ready to eat. Serve as is or with Strawberry Topping.

text:
Left 4 Dead 2, a game that has left me feeling thoroughly disappointed and disenchanted. In my humble opinion, this popular title fails to deliver on multiple fronts, leaving a bitter taste in my gaming palate. Allow me to elaborate on my grievances.
First and foremost, Left 4 Dead 2's greatest sin lies in its overt simplicity. The gameplay mechanics, while initially promising, quickly devolve into a monotonous cycle of repetitive actions. The lack of depth and complexity hampers any potential for engaging strategy or meaningful decision-making. It feels like a relentless onslaught of mindless hordes, devoid of any true challenge or intellectual stimulation.
Furthermore, my discontent grows as I examine the character selection. One cannot help but be dismayed by the inclusion of Coach, a character who seems to dominate a disproportionate share of the roster. The lack of diversity and variety in character choices is a disheartening oversight, further exacerbating the game's already overwhelming sense of tedium.
As I traversed the game's bleak environments, the visuals failed to captivate or impress. The graphics, while serviceable, lack the polish and finesse that one would expect from a modern title. The unremarkable textures and uninspired level design contribute to an overall lackluster visual experience, further diminishing any potential enjoyment that could be derived from the game.
Moreover, Left 4 Dead 2's narrative fails to engross or engage. The shallow plot, if it can even be called that, provides little motivation or incentive to continue playing. The absence of compelling character arcs or a gripping storyline leaves players adrift in a sea of indifference, detached from the game's world and its inhabitants.
In conclusion, Left 4 Dead 2 falls short of expectations on multiple fronts, rendering it an unremarkable and unenjoyable experience. Its simplistic gameplay, lack of character diversity, underwhelming visuals, and uninspired narrative collectively contribute to a lackluster affair. I find it difficult to recommend this game to anyone seeking a satisfying and engaging zombie survival experience. It is a lackluster addition to the genre, leaving much to be desired in terms of depth, innovation, and overall enjoyment.

I use to spend 12hrs/day playing Quake-3 excessive servers, grenade jumping 200 feet into the air pulling out my railgun, & sniping players as I fell to the ground... never ever got as sick as a 20-30 min game of this does (not even when I had the flu did I ever feel this nauseous!) Why?!? I think it's a combination of the screen shaking, AND flashing with every pull of the trigger for my preferred dual wield pistols, every time you get hit the screen blinks, shakes, or BOTH, you get status effects, & the screen either shakes, or blinks (or turns colors too), AND every step, or jump has the screen shaking strangely... there's a DARN good reason MOST game devs give the options to turn these things OFF! I ran around at night in Iraq, with flares flashing, lights blinking, bombs, & grenades going off all around me, shooting either an M16, or sniper rifle, and never once got sick to my stomach, the devs who put these kind of effects into shooters are like the guys who put tons of motion blur in racing games, they've never done the actual activity, so they have NO CLUE what the experience is actually like, & their ideas come from hollywood movies. EVERYTHING else about this game seems really neat, I mean I've twice now (years apart, hoping the game had changed with updates) tried playing this with friends, only to get so sick I not only had to stop playing, but the nausea was SO bad, that I still felt sick over 24hrs later... The game runs smooth, would most likely run on a potato, controls great once you use Steam to switch your buttons to something that makes sense, doesn't lag online (I was literally playing it with a guy who lives 1/2 way around the globe, we had NO lag), sounds great, the maps, enemies, & characters are done WELL, & look/animate GREAT... so if Steam had a rating system instead of thumbs up/down, I'd give this a 7/10, minus 3 for no option to turn off the 3 things that cause motion sickness, otherwise the game's GREAT, so try it if you like such games (it goes on sale A LOT, so wait for one), & if it doesn't make you ill, count your blessings, & enjoy it, sadly I cannot.

text:
As a diehard fan of the first Left 4 Dead game, I had high expectations for Left 4 Dead 2. Unfortunately, after playing this so-called "sequel," I can confidently say that it's a massive f**king letdown.

Let's start with the goddamn characters. While the original Left 4 Dead had a lovable and memorable cast, Left 4 Dead 2 feels like a cheap knockoff with uninspired and forgettable characters. They lack the depth, charm, and chemistry of the first game's survivors, making me wonder if the developers even cared about making them interesting.

Speaking of uninspired, let's talk about the goddamn campaigns. Left 4 Dead 2's campaigns feel like lazy rehashes of the first game's levels, with nothing new or exciting to offer. Sure, the settings may be different, but the gameplay and objectives are practically the same. It's as if the developers ran out of ideas and decided to copy-paste everything from the first game.

And don't even get me started on the goddamn melee weapons. What the fk were they thinking? The first game's emphasis on ranged combat and teamwork was what made it so thrilling and intense. Left 4 Dead 2's addition of melee weapons only serves to dumb down the gameplay and make it feel like a hack-and-slash mess. It's as if the developers forgot what made the first game so great and decided to cater to braindead players who just want to swing a fking baseball bat.

Let's not forget the godawful A.I. in Left 4 Dead 2. The survivors and the infected feel like braindead idiots who can't do anything right. They get stuck on geometry, they don't follow your commands, and they constantly put themselves in danger without a second thought. It's like the developers wanted to make the game more frustrating and less enjoyable for everyone involved.

Lastly, the goddamn realism mode. While it may sound like a good idea on paper, the reality is that it's a f**king mess. The game was not designed with realism in mind, leading to absurd situations where the survivors can't even carry a first-aid kit without dropping their primary weapon. It's as if the developers wanted to punish players for wanting a more challenging experience.

Overall, Left 4 Dead 2 is a fking disappointment that falls short of its predecessor in every way. From the uninspired characters and campaigns to the braindead A.I. and dumbed-down gameplay, this game feels like a lazy cash grab that doesn't deserve to carry the Left 4 Dead name. Stick with the first game and avoid this piece of st at all costs.

But the next ugliest part is that it's ingrained into even the common infected's animations, so having low lerp settings makes them janky, jittery, sporadic messes that are incoherent which is sad because having low lerp settings makes the actual core gameplay more reliable. There's a reason custom servers like to run 100 tick servers and do away with a lot of the lerp nonsense.

- Typical toxic community playerbase, lots of racists, bigots, griefers, and cheaters. Reprobates through and through. Obviously, not everyone you meet will be like them, but there's an embarrassing amount of them.

- Stupid and obnoxious modded servers everywhere, you can put the offending server ips onto a blacklist using the `status`, `addip`, `listip`, and `writeip` commands, and load the blacklist every time you open the game via `exec banned_ips`, or alternatively tell your firewall not to allow those ips to connect. This doesn't remove the ips from the server list or prevent the game from attempting to connect to them, it instead means the connection attempts will never be [i]successful[/i], which leaves you sitting on a loading screen until you timeout. (Terrible UX).

- Bad in-client matchmaking, you can select "Quick Match" -> "Official Dedicated Servers" and the game will put you into random lobbies that your neighbour hosts rather than a Valve official server. Having to open the server browser defeats the entire purpose behind why they decided to make this matchmaking UX to begin with -- they didn't want to just put another server browser there like they did in TF2 and wanted a less intimidating interface for players.

If you sink any amount of actual time into this game it will be apparent that it is not here to be enjoyed.

text:
I picked this game up because a friend wanted me to play it, have a about ~500 hours in it as of now but haven't played it for more than a few over the past few months.

I'm sure this game was better in its prime day back when valve used to actually care about giving their games SOME form of live service, but now it's just pretty dog shit.

The game is pretty meh when it comes to balance. Most of the special infecteds kinda suck and can only really single out players and hope they cram in as much damage as possible before getting instantly obliterated by their teammates or just shove spammed into a corner and then lined up for an easy headshot. So you have to eloquently coordinate a symphony of attacks to even do anything to somebody. On the flipside, survivors are OP as a team but completely dog shit on their own. One survivor on their own will easily get mauled by less than 10 AI zombies even if they have melees and will get completely a55raeped, and so the only thing saving survivors is other survivors.

So you can kinda see where the main issue with this game lies, in that it's heavily team-based as a casual game with very little opportunity for either side to individually perform well. Yeah, if you're in a 4 stack squad with your friends against some randoms in a pub, you'll have an absolute pummeling your opponents. But if you're up against another 4 stack of crazy tryhards or, god forbid you submit yourself to this torture, you play WITHOUT friends, then you're royally fvvkkced.

And since this game has a community of sweaty tryhards who play it like an esport mixed in with noobs or casuals, you can pretty easily see how awful it can feel to randomly queue up against a 4 stack and get steamrolled with no ability to carry all because you wanted to hop on a few rounds of L4D2. Maybe when this game came out like 15+ years ago, it was more fun and dynamic when everybody kinda screwed around for fun and didn't take it too seriously, but now with all the sweaty no lifes who love pubstomping, you'll need to find your 4 man queue of other tryhards in order to really have fun. \\

And if that's your thing, go for it. If it's not, then don't waste your time playing this.

On top of that, there are SO many cheaters in this game. Whether it's people with bhop scripts, aimbot, wallhacks, auto shove, etc. This game has ALL of it. It's kinda sad that people do this but hey it's a valve game what do you expect. It's like every other lobby i'm in there's some dude cranking out 180 headshots who's invincible to smoker tongues and hunter leaps no matter how perfectly I time it.

And to add more frosting on the cake, this game has dog shit hitboxes and registry, probably due to the fact that it's old, meaning you have to predict where you will collide with a player almost a full second later rather than actually just timing it on your screen. And again, i get it, it's an old game with old servers but i don't care, it ruins the experience lol. I can't count the number of times i've literally collided with a player model on my screen as charger and STILL, STILL not have it register in the server despite the fact that my charger is stuck running in place on their player model for a full second on my screen. And i'll check the ping values on the player list and it'll show me with the lowest possible ping (15-30 MS) out of anybody else in the lobby, so i know it's not my internet.

overall, dead cringe game that's poorly balanced, poorly designed, way outdated from a tech standpoint, and infested with too many cheaters who can't stand to lose fairly and need to win with a crutch.

I remember the good, fun days- when i was 5, or 7? Who cares, but not a worry in the world, me n' my dad on his bed, watching him play the hours away after a long day of him in the oilfield. Not a worry in the world when I was in that room, right? Just me, him, and hordes of hordes of zombies. And now, picking up the game years later...I miss it.
Well, I miss the nostalgia, more of- those were the best years of my life, elementary school and L4D.
But now, the spark is just..gone. It bores me, and I wish i could have the same joy as picking up the controller for the first time, the first kill, the first Smoker grabbing onto Louis and choking hi to death as i try and hit the smoker with a pistol (missed every shot), only for a hunter to jump on me immedietly after..
I'm sorry valve. I'll miss this game, and it'll forever hold a place in my heart as the one that started the never-ending, burning fire of entertainment and joy that games can bring a person to this day.
Goodbye, L4D, you'll always be held dearly in my heart.

text:
Let me rephrase my review so it doesn't sound like I went in, got two bad games and then shat all over the steam review box.

I've been around this game community a long time ago.
Was always a huge Valve games fan, back in the day where they actually made games.

Left 4 Dead 1 took me by a storm, I bought it on the release day, played the HELL out of it, participated in dozens of communities, even got to the Top 10 in the "Garena" L4D communityu of my country. Game was one of my favorites for sure. 

Then Left 4 dead 2 came, It felt like a total upgrade, specially when they added the L4D1 content. The new specials were challenging, the new weapons were cool, and the newly dismembering feature (which was brand-new at the time) was amazing and satisfying.

Some of my hours are not clocked into this account because I used another account at the time.

So. After a while, of course I moved on. Not every game I'll go crazy 5000 hours like I did with Payday 2.

Then recently I saw a video of my friend playing it and felt like trying again. Missed the simpler times.

Oh boy I was wrong.
Of course, I had a handful of great games, even got an achievement for finishing dead center before the first tank spawned, met some cool peeps, alright, cool, cool.

But then I had people purposely friendly-fire others, shooting every car they see, locking people outside, doing all sorts of childish shenanigans and spamming a lot of crap in the chat that would definitely get the social media platforms of nowadays very angry with them. lol.

I shrugged, and kept going. Found another team of lads, same thing, different MO.

Kept going, yep, same thing.

Then at some point I got enough and asked some guys that were already going psycho on the mic:

"Why are you guys playing a coop videogame if you all you want is havoc chaos to other players, there are better platforms to do that."

He laughed and then told me I'm the one who was wrong, because "This game Main objective is Versus, and this "other gamemode" was not meant to be taken seriously, specially because it was such an old game, lmao, lol, kek, etc."

That's when I quit and uninstalled.

What I assumed that happened was that a bunch of late Gen Z's found the game, said "lmao so old lmao lmao lol kek" as they usually do and then just decided to fuck around, which is fine if the game is meant to be like that. But this ain't one.

Now the concept of the community is so twisted that people will behave in this way thinking THIS is how the game was always supposed to be played.

This is why I'm highly against coop games getitng a pvp mode. It attracts THAT type of people. They don't like 100% coop games because it's "too boring" for them. And thank God it is.

So my review was: If you're from the era I was, please play with only friends or just go solo. The CURRENT community kinda fuc ked the pub games.
